summary: inTRODUCTION Rotavirus (RV) is the most common cause of viral gastroenteritis in young children and infants worldwide (1, 2). it is a nonenveloped RNA virus with a genome composed of 11 segments of double-stranded RNA (dsRNA), which replicates in cytoplasmic structures composed primarily of viral proteins (3–5). the first steps of viral morphogenesis and genome replication occur within cytoplasmic viral replication factories known as viroplasm NSP5 hyperphosphorylation involves the phosphorylation of serine 67 (Ser67) by casein kinase 1 (CK1) to initiate the phosphorylation cascade. the structure of NSP5 remains unknown, but readily forms oligomeric species in solution. previous studies on NSP5 have been carried out using mutants expressed in the absence of a complete set of viral proteins. recombinant rotaviruses (simian rotavirus A strain SA11) carrying different mutations in the NSP5 coding region of gs11 were obtained using a recently developed reverse-genetics protocol. two essential additional modifications were introduced to trans-complement the potential loss of NSP5 function in the rRV mutants. rRV-NSP5/KO. NSP5 expression and localization to viroplasms in virus-infected cells have been considered essential for virus replication. previous studies, using small interfering RNA targeting gs11 mRNA, have shown strong impairment of RV replication (12, 13) rRV-NSP5/KO strain does not replicate in MA-NSP5-EGFP cells. both genomic dsRNA synthesis (Fig. 2D) and infectious progeny virus production were completely abrogated in MA104 cells. together, these data confirm that NSP5 is essential for RV replication. rRV-NSP5/KO strain grown in MA-NSP5 or MA104 cells. data are expressed as means standard deviations (n = 3); **, P 0.01 (Student's t test). rRVs with impaired NSP5 phosphorylation. virus-infected cell extracts detected at 5 or 10 h postinfection (hpi). phosphorylation with -protein phosphatase (-Ppase) and alkaline calf intestinal Ppase (CIP) was previously used to discriminate phosphorylated from nonphosphorylated NSP5. the NSP5 band with the fastest PAGE mobility has been described as 26 kDa. Western blot analysis of -Ppase and alkaline Ppase treatment of lysates of MA104 cells infected with rRV-wt or rRV-NSP5/S67A. protein bands corresponding to NSP5 are shown. we then generated two additional rRVs harboring truncated versions of NSP5, one lacking the 18-aa-long C-terminal tail (rRV-NSP5/T) rRV-NSP5/T and rRV-NSP5/176-180 grown in MA-NSP5 and MA104 cells. we also investigated viroplasm formation in cells infected with these rRV mutants. during early infection (5 hpi), the rRV-NSP5/S67A mutant produced structures resembling viroplasms that appeared smaller and more heterogeneous in shape. micrographs of rRV-wt- and rRV-NSP5/S67A-infected MA104 cells stained at 10 hpi with the indicated antibodies. structures produced by rRV-NSP5/S67A were morphologically similar to those observed during wt RV infection of MA104 cells silenced for CK1. rRV-wt-infected mutants yielded fiber-like structures containing only the VP6 protein. similar VP6 fibers are normally formed when VP6 is overexpressed in cells in the absence of other viral proteins. these results confirm the role of NSP5 hyperphosphorylation for controlling the assembly of regular-shaped viroplasms. confocal immunofluorescence micrographs of MA104, MA-NSP2-mCherry, and MA-NSP5 (lower panel) cells stained with anti-NSP5 and 5-EU (green) single-molecule RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization of MA-NSP5-EGFP cells infected with rRV-wt, rRV-NSP5/S67A. at 10 hpi, abundant gs6 transcripts could be detected in all viroplasms identified in MA-NSP5-EGFP cells infected with rRV-wt. smFISH performed on cells infected with rRV-NSP5/T showed diffuse distribution of gs6 RNA that did not localize to any structures resembling viroplasms. lipid membranes could be identified in cells infected with rRV-NSP5/S67A mutant. the observed immature viroplasms appeared to be less electron dense. these data strongly support the role of NSP5 phosphorylation in maintaining viral RNA production and genome replication in viroplasms.
